price_to_income_index: This is the basic measure for apartment purchase affordability. It measures how many years of earning a median income it would take to pay a mortgage on an averagely priced apartment. </br> </br> The top value is Havana, Cuba, where it's estimated that it would take 48 years to pay off a mortgage.
yield_centre: Yield is the total yearly rent divided by the property price. A low yield signifies that the rent value per month is a small percentage of the actual property value.</br> </br> In Central Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei it costs over 34 times more to buy than it does to rent property.
yield_outer: Yield is the total yearly rent divided by the property price. A low yield signifies that the rent value per month is a small percentage of the actual property value.</br> </br> Notice how major american cities rental prices are very high compared to property price.
rent_centre: This is the ratio between the average price per square meter to buy, and the average price per square meter to rent. A high ratio suggests that rents are high compared to actual cost to buy a place. </br> </br> In central Nagpur in India and Taipei in Taiwan itâ€™s over 60 times more to buy per square meter than it is to rent.
rent_outer: This is the ratio between the average price per square meter to buy, and the average price per square meter to rent in a city's outskirts. A high ratio suggests that rents are high compared to actual cost to buy a place.</br> </br> In almost all cities in the USA, buying in the outskirts is around 6-8 times more than it is to rent.
mort_income: A ratio of the actual monthly cost of an average mortgage to average take-home family income. This calculates the percentage of income that is spent on a mortgage of a median sized home. </br> </br> Any orange and red lines show places where this is nearly, or even over 100%
afford_index: This index scales the mortgage to income ratio. Green values show places where average income is enough to afford an average mortgage with some comfort.
